item.title: [PI] Spawning items by name
item.dc:creator: @n10si_t n10si t
item.description:
@n10si_t wrote:

[quote=“Andrew Ferguson, post:7, topic:394681”][quote author=I Vain I via MSN]
is it so hard to do this:

if (playerCommand.equalsIgnoreCase("spawn")) { String[] args = playerCommand.split(" "); for (int i = 1; i < args.length; i++) String name = args[i] + " "; c.getItems().addItem(c.getItems().getItemId(name), 1); }?[/quote][/quote]

oh that kicks the shit out of what i did, and i made it way easier

item.title: [PI] Spawning items by name
item.dc:creator: @n10si_t n10si t
item.description:
@n10si_t wrote:

holy shit:

if (playerCommand.startsWith("item") && c.playerRights >= 2) {

				try {

					String[] args = playerCommand.split(" ");

					if (args.length == 3) {

						int newItemID = c.getItems().getItemId(args[1]);

						int newItemAmount = Integer.parseInt(args[2]);

						if ((newItemID <= 20000) && (newItemID >= 0)) {

							c.getItems().addItem(newItemID, newItemAmount);		

						} else {

							c.sendMessage("No such item.");

						}

					} else {

						c.sendMessage("Use as ::pickup itemname");

					}

				} catch(Exception e) {

					

				}

			}

::item toolkit 1

item.title: [PI] Spawning items by name
item.dc:creator: @revengr revengr
item.description:
@revengr wrote:

Does anyone find it a hassle to have to go look up an item on an ID list just to spawn something if you don’t have the ID memorized?
I have, so I decided to make a few commands to make your spawning easier.

I made these commands out of 100% scrap.
Credits to anyone else are not needed.

I’m sorry if my conventions aren’t up to your standards.
I did my best to perfect the indentions, and that’s good enough for me.

First, open up server.model.players.Player.java, and declare these variables:

public boolean ibnInitialized = false; public boolean quantityRequest_LIST = false; public boolean quantityRequest_SINGLE = false; public int ibnSRHolder = -1;

NOTE: On my server, these variables are actually declared in Client.java.
If you have any issues with these four variables, try moving them to Client.java.

All four of these variables are used if you want to input a quantity for the spawned items.

ibnInitialized keeps the server from throwing a NullPointerException.
I included this because I haven’t worked with arrays initialized with “new int” before.

quantityRequested becomes true if you used ::ibnx or ::ibnlistx.
quantityRequested_SINGLE for ::ibnx, quantityRequested_LIST for ::ibnlistx.

ibnSRHolder holds the item ID of the clicked item while you input the desired quantity.

Still in Player.java, declare these int arrays:

[code]
public int[] ibnResult = new int[100];

public int[] questListTextID = {7332, 7333, 7334, 7336, 7383, 7339, 7338, 7340, 7346, 7341, 7342, 7337, 7343, 7335, 7344,
7345, 7347, 7348, 12772, 673, 7352, 17510, 7353, 12129, 8438, 12852, 15841, 7354, 7355,
7356, 8679, 7459, 16149, 6987, 7357, 12836, 7358, 7359, 14169, 10115, 14604, 7360, 12282,
13577, 12839, 7361, 16128, 11857, 7362, 7363, 7364, 10135, 4508, 18517, 11907, 7365, 7366,
7367, 13389, 15487, 7368, 11132, 7369, 12389, 13974, 6027, 7370, 8137, 7371, 12345, 7372,
8115, 18684, 15499, 18306, 668, 8576, 12139, 14912, 7373, 7374, 8969, 15352, 7375, 7376,
15098, 15592, 249, 1740, 15235, 3278, 7378, 6518, 7379, 7380, 7381, 11858, 191, 9927, 6024};
public int[] questListButtonID = {28164, 28165, 28166, 28168, 28215, 28171, 28170, 28172, 28178, 28173, 28174, 28169, 28175,
28167, 28176, 28177, 28179, 28180, 49228, 2161, 28184, 68102, 28185, 47097, 32246, 50052,
61225, 28186, 28187, 28188, 33231, 29035, 63021, 27075, 28189, 50036, 28190, 28191, 55089,
39131, 57012, 28192, 47250, 53009, 50039, 28193, 63000, 46081, 28194, 28195, 28196, 39151,
17156, 72085, 46131, 28197, 28198, 28199, 52077, 60127, 28200, 43124, 28201, 48101, 54150,
23139, 28202, 31201, 28203, 48057, 28204, 31179, 72252, 60139, 71130, 2156, 33128, 47107,
58064, 28205, 28206, 35009, 59248, 28207, 28208, 58250, 60232, 249, 6204, 59131, 12206,
28210, 25118, 28211, 28212, 28213, 46082, 191, 38199, 23136}; [/code]

The length of these arrays are all the same, so they can be synchronized correctly.

ibnResult[] contains the ID’s for results returned from the ::ibnlist/::ibnlistx command.

questListTextID[] contains the ID’s for the first 100 text lines in the quest menu in order from top to bottom.
questListButtonID[] contains the ID’s for the first 100 clickable lines in the quest menu in order from top to bottom.

Open up server.model.players.packets.BankX2.java

Under this line…

Paste this…

if (c.ibnSRHolder > -1) { c.sendMessage("Returned Item: "+c.getItems().getItemName(c.ibnSRHolder)+" (x"+Xamount+")"); c.getItems().addItem(c.ibnSRHolder, Xamount); c.ibnSRHolder = -1; if (c.quantityRequest_SINGLE) c.quantityRequest_SINGLE = false; return; }

This number is always -1, unless you clicked one of the results in the quest list.

c.sendMessage("Returned Item: "+c.getItems().getItemName(c.ibnSRHolder)+" (x"+Xamount+")"); c.getItems().addItem(c.ibnSRHolder, Xamount);
Spawns the clicked item in the quantity entered, and sends a message containing the item’s name and the entered quantity.

Resets the item ID holder variable.

if (c.quantityRequest_SINGLE) c.quantityRequest_SINGLE = false;
Resets the c.quantityRequest_SINGLE variable, which is used in the ::ibnx command.

Open server.model.players.packets.ClickingButtons.java

Above this line…

[/code][code]switch (actionButtonId) {

Paste this…

[/code][code]for(int i = 0; i < c.questListButtonID.length; i++) { if (actionButtonId == c.questListButtonID[i] && c.ibnInitialized) { if (c.ibnResult[i] > -1) { if (c.getItems().freeSlots() > 0) { if (c.quantityRequest_LIST) { c.ibnSRHolder = c.ibnResult[i]; c.getOutStream().createFrame(27); } else { c.getItems().addItem(c.ibnResult[i], 1); c.sendMessage("Spawned "+c.getItems().getItemName(c.ibnResult[i])+"."); } } else { c.sendMessage("Your inventory is full!"); } } return; } }

Loops the following 100 times.

if (actionButtonId == c.questListButtonID[i] && c.ibnInitialized) { if (c.ibnResult[i] > -1) { if (c.getItems().freeSlots() > 0) {
If the button you clicked is the same as the button ID in the current spot in the questListButtonArray, you used the ::ibnlist/::ibnlistx command, the clicked line has a result in it, and you have space in your inventory, then continue.

if (c.quantityRequest_LIST) { c.ibnSRHolder = c.ibnResult[i]; c.getOutStream().createFrame(27); } else { c.getItems().addItem(c.ibnResult[i], 1); c.sendMessage("Spawned "+c.getItems().getItemName(c.ibnResult[i])+"."); }
If used ::ibnlistx, then add the clicked item ID to the placeholder, and send a message to the client prompting the user for a numerical input. If used ::ibnlist, then spawn the clicked item and send a notification message with the item’s name.

If one of the buttons in the array matched the clicked button, then there is no reason to go on.

Open up server.model.players.packets.Commands.java, and initialize this variable…

… and add this in with your administrator commands.

http://pastebin.com/FrDs2Q48
(I had to use pastebin, because the commands made me go over 20,000 characters.)

I’m only going to explain the first command, ::ibn/::ibnx
The other commands are very similar. Only a few lines are actually changed.

Makes sure your using ::ibn/::ibnx, and not ::ibnall or ::ibnlist/::ibnlistx.

if (c.getItems().freeSlots() == 0) { c.sendMessage("You cannot use this command when your inventory is full."); return; }Your inventory is full. Don’t proceed.

String inputName = ""; if (playerCommand.startsWith("ibnx")) { inputName = playerCommand.substring(5); c.quantityRequest_SINGLE = true; } else { inputName = playerCommand.substring(4); c.quantityRequest_SINGLE = false; }
Initialize the search term variable.
If you used ::ibnx, start the search term at the 5th char. Otherwise, start at the 4th.
Make c.quantityRequest_SINGLE true if you used ::ibnx, because you want the server to ask how much of the desired item you want. Otherwise, make it false.

Makes the search term all lower-case. This is necessary to make sure the command is completley NON-case-sensitive.

If the search term does contain a space, and isn’t surrounded with apostrophes, then…

String[] args = inputName.split(" "); for (int i = 0; i < Server.itemHandler.ItemList.length; i++) { if (Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i] != null) { String listedName = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemName; listedName = listedName.toLowerCase(); if(listedName.contains(" ")) { String[] args2 = listedName.split(" ");
Split the search term into args, loop through the item list, and split all items whose names contain spaces into args, and convert them to lower-case (once again, for the sake of non-case-sensitive).

If both the search term and the item name has the same amount of spaces, then continue. If not, skip to the next item.

int count = 0; for(int j = 0; j < args.length; j++) { if(args[j].startsWith("*") && !args[j].endsWith("*") && !args[j].startsWith("'") && !args[j].endsWith("'")) { if(args2[j].endsWith(args[j].replace("*", ""))) count++; } else if(args[j].endsWith("*") && !args[j].startsWith("*") && !args[j].startsWith("'") && !args[j].endsWith("'")) { if(args2[j].startsWith(args[j].replace("*", ""))) count++; } else if(args[j].startsWith("'") && args[j].endsWith("'") && !args[j].contains("*")) { if(args2[j].equals(args[j].replace("'", ""))) count++; } else if(!args[j].contains("*") && !args[j].startsWith("'") && !args[j].endsWith("'")) { if(args2[j].contains(args[j])) count++; } }
Initialize a counter variable, and begin comparing each arg. Each time an arg compares correctly, then increase the counter by 1.

If the counter is the same as the amount of args, then all the args compared, and the item is a valid result.

if (c.quantityRequest_SINGLE) { c.ibnSRHolder = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId; c.getOutStream().createFrame(27); return; } else { c.getItems().addItem(Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId, 1); c.sendMessage("Returned item: "+Misc.optimizeText(listedName)+""); return; }If you used ::ibnx, then add the returned item’s ID to the placeholder variable, and tell the client to prompt the player for a numerical input. Otherwise, just spawn one of the returned item, and send a notification message.

The search term contained no spaces, so do not break the term and item names up into args. Instead, just compare the term with the entire item name.

for (int i = 0; i < Server.itemHandler.ItemList.length; i++) { if (Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i] != null) { String listedName = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemName; listedName = listedName.toLowerCase();The same as before, only don’t split the item name and the search term into args.

if(inputName.startsWith("*") && !inputName.endsWith("*") && !inputName.startsWith("'") && !inputName.endsWith("'")) { if(listedName.endsWith(inputName.replace("*", ""))) { if (c.quantityRequest_SINGLE) { c.ibnSRHolder = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId; c.getOutStream().createFrame(27); return; } else { c.getItems().addItem(Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId, 1); c.sendMessage("Returned item: "+Misc.optimizeText(listedName)+""); return; } } }The search term had an asterisk at the beginning of it. Therefore, if the item name ends with the search term, then it is a valid result. Use the same result method from before.

if(inputName.endsWith("*") && !inputName.startsWith("*") && !inputName.startsWith("'") && !inputName.endsWith("'")) { if(listedName.startsWith(inputName.replace("*", ""))) { if (c.quantityRequest_SINGLE) { c.ibnSRHolder = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId; c.getOutStream().createFrame(27); return; } else { c.getItems().addItem(Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId, 1); c.sendMessage("Returned item: "+Misc.optimizeText(listedName)+""); return; } } }The search term ended with an apostrophe, so if the item’s name starts with the search term, then it is a valid result. Same result method as before.

if(inputName.startsWith("'") && inputName.endsWith("'") && !inputName.contains("*")) { if(listedName.equals(inputName.replace("'", ""))) { if (c.quantityRequest_SINGLE) { c.ibnSRHolder = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId; c.getOutStream().createFrame(27); return; } else { c.getItems().addItem(Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId, 1); c.sendMessage("Returned item: "+Misc.optimizeText(listedName)+""); return; } } }The search term started and ended with an apostrophe. If the item name matches the search term exactly, then it is a valid result. Same result method as before.

if(!inputName.contains("*") && !inputName.startsWith("'") && !inputName.endsWith("'")) { if(listedName.contains(inputName)) { if (c.quantityRequest_SINGLE) { c.ibnSRHolder = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId; c.getOutStream().createFrame(27); return; } else { c.getItems().addItem(Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId, 1); c.sendMessage("Returned item: "+Misc.optimizeText(listedName)+""); return; } } }The search term didn’t have any asterisks, and wasn’t surrounded in apostrophes. If the item name contains the search term, then it is a valid result. Same result method as before.

Everytime a result is returned, the method is ended. If the server reached this line, then no results we’re returned. Notify the player.

Differences between commands:

::ibnall

c.getItems().addItem(Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId, 1); c.sendMessage("Returned item: "+Misc.optimizeText(listedName)+""); results += 1; if (c.getItems().freeSlots() == 0) { c.sendMessage("Your inventory is full!"); c.sendMessage(""+results+" results were returned."); return; }
This is called when the item is a valid result. Instead of ending the method, the loop continues its search for more results. If the inventory is full, then the loop breaks.

::ibnlist

for(int z = 0; z < c.questListTextID.length; z++) { c.ibnResult[z] = -1; c.getPA().sendFrame126("", c.questListTextID[z]); } c.ibnInitialized = true; c.getPA().sendFrame126("Results", 663);
Clears all lines in the quest list, and resets the result placeholders. Switches the ibnInitialized to true, which is called in ClickingButtons. Displays the text “Results” at the top of the quest list.

Resets the spot variable.

c.ibnResult[spot] = Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId; c.getPA().sendFrame126("@gre@"+Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemName+" ("+Server.itemHandler.ItemList[i].itemId+")", c.questListTextID[spot]); spot++; results++;
This is called when the item is a valid result. The item’s ID is added to the current spot in the result placeholder array, the item’s name is added to the current line in the quest menu, and the spot and results variables increases by one.

if (results == 100) break;
The maximum amount of results has been reached. Break the loop.

if(results == 0) c.sendMessage("No results were returned."); else c.sendMessage(""+results+" results were returned.");Tells the player how many results were returned.

Also, each command uses try and catch to prevent the player from crashing in-case of an error when processesing the command.

Here is a text document I created that explains the function of the command and how to use it.
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/10361641/Usage%20of%20IBN.txt

Let me know if the link dies.

Comments? Questions? Suggestions? Issues?
Please reply.

I will be reposting this on r-s under the name xxx9234.

Read full topic
